body: Oh, Rollup will by default cache the first result of tree-shaking inside try-statements. One workaround, set `treeshake.tryCatchDeoptimization` to `false` https://rollupjs.org/configuration-options/#treeshake-trycatchdeoptimization
I'm thinking this option might need to be deprecated. After enabling tree-shaking for object, Rollup should always perform tree-shaking inside `try` statements.
The problem is that polyfills rely on this behavior as some do feature detection by expecting that "valid" code throws.

issue.title: Revert  object tree-shaking (#5420) until some issues have been resolved
issue.body:
This reverts commit a9acb5730e9c5f02598088af311fb3a02686e471.

where 1234 is the issue number. This will help us with house-keeping as Github will automatically add a note to those issues stating that a potential fix exists. Once the PR is merged, Github will automatically close those issues.

Starting each line with a dash "-" will cause GitHub to display the issue title inline.

I will revert the feature for now until #5733, #5734, #5735 and https://github.com/rollup/rollup/issues/5480#issuecomment-2482179159 have been fixed. We also need to see if we can improve upon #5729.

body: Perhaps we could consider limiting this option to only affect `hasEffects` detection and remove its impact on `includePath`?

body: We are noticing this type of problem in a very large project with 4.27.3. Causing crashes in our Quasar/Vue application - don't have a replication for you at the moment, but we've traced that an array is being passed in and comes out the other side as an empty array. Note this has been working for months. Had another serious breakage on Friday that was similar. I can give more details, but right now I need to find a way to force Quasar's build routine to use an older version so we can keep working.
Are you sure it is 4.27.3? This version reverts the feature and is mostly equivalent to 4.26
Yes. We are sure. Trying some different things now to see if we can narrow it down.

A bit of a false alarm, sorry. However, we've clearly traced a bunch of problems to the Vue update on Friday. It just happens that, whatever additionally broke there with the update from Vue 3.3.8 to 3.5.x also creating similar evidencing.

This issue has been resolved via #5737 as part of rollup@4.29.0-0. Note that this is a pre-release, so to test it, you need to install Rollup via `npm install rollup@4.29.0-0` or `npm install rollup@beta`. It will likely become part of a regular release later.
